Put me down in support of Professor Piketty's approach to examining the increase in income and wealth concentration before taxes. Our system of government by We the People, & our society are being undermined by the steady increase in concentration of income & wealth. We know it. We have known it for decades & government has NOT progressed in making our society more egalitarian & providing opportunity for all to succeed according to their own abilities. Our society & our government has failed in the education of our children & failed in giving them an opportunity to escape poverty. This week I paid for early boarding, for the first time, only to discover the "zone 1" boarding I paid for actually came after the following: the elderly, disabled and people with children; first class passengers; and something called "Delta Sky Zone," which appeared to be about half the people waiting to board. When my "preferred" group finally got to board, I walked to the back of the plane, where my seat was, only to discover the aisle seat was occupied by one of the "disabled" people who had been wheelchaired on in the first group. It turned out (she told me) she wasn't being met by a wheelchair at our destination (Palm Beach) because she didn't really need one, simply preferring one at LaGuardia because it is so chaotic there. So that is one good way to get on early and get that overhead space -- simply request a wheelchair and of course make sure to generously tip the wheelchair pusher.

On my way home I flew first class. I was the last first class passenger to board and there was barely any space left in the overhead space for my small duffel bag. When we disembarked at LGA I had to fight my way out of the gate area as people waiting to fly out were surging toward the gate, apparently eager to get on the plane with their wheelies. It reminded me of experiences fighting my way off New York subway trains when people waiting to board refuse to let people off first.

To Wifely Person: I'd suggest amending your first sentence to read, "The Unites States ranks 99th, right beside tiny San Marino, on a list of countries in order of percentage of LEADERS in national leadership roles."

Our current batch of leaders is failing period.

We are neither liberated nor liberal. We are a mess lead by reactionaries. We are so far from "exceptional", in a positive sense, that we are below average. This country merits a C- on most measures of progressiveness and true equality.
Yet many women think feminism is not necessary because "we've already won the war." The right's agenda to misdefine and tarnish feminism was amazingly successful.

The Unites States ranks 99th, right beside tiny San Marino, on a list of countries in order of percentage of women in national leadership roles. 98 other countries with more women involved in national politics that ours. Rawanda tops the list, with 64% in the lower house and 39% of the upper house seats held by women. We are at 18% in the House and 20% in the Senate.

What's amazing is that we have a "liberated" society, yet gender is still a factor in politics, in corporate America, in academic America, and even in artistic America. That women make up over 50% of the population suggests that there remains some kind of basic gender issue.

The late Dr. Linda Brodsky, who spent much of career fighting gender inequality in medicine, concluded that it wasn't about equal ability, it was mostly about "old boy networks" working to maintain a status quo. Women get the same education, often have similar opening opportunities, but are more likely to hit the glass ceiling about halfway up the ladder.

We've not progressed anywhere near far enough. The fundamental divide between men and women on both sides of the aisle remains intact. And it's exacerbated by women like Terri Lynn Land who actively work hard to preserve it and, in turn, help to keep women from moving forward.

Bella Abzug said it best:
"The test for whether or not you can hold a job should not be the arrangement of your chromosomes."

The USS Coles was neither docked nor undefended; it was moored at anchor in mid harbor, with a full complement of crew evidently not paying attention to the harbor traffic and thus a sitting duck for the fast speed boat loaded with explosives which rammed her amidships at full throttle in a suicide attack. Clearly she should have had an escort of picket boats at a minimum as protection; she did not; a stupid error by the US Navy and her commander.

Poor security precautions have occurred previously, the most notable being Beirut, Lebanon during the Reagan era resulting in the deaths of over 200 US marines in eerily similar circumstances when a truck bomb was driven into their barracks in a suicide attack.

Elementary normal high security, a standard required imperative in a hostile environment was overlooked in both cases. Highly reminiscent of the Benghazi debacle, the main difference being the smaller scale in loss of life, the Ambassador and three other young Americans. The repeated requests by US personnel in Benghazi for increased security in the weeks prior to the attack were met with denials of those requests for added security by the US State Department. No one took responsibility, no one has been charged or prosecuted or tried for dereliction of duty. Finally Congress has decided to have a full scale inquiry into the Benghazi outrage following failed attempts previously intentionally impeded by administration stonewalling. Finally time for the truth to be unveiled.

"Assuming the facts are as portrayed"?  I don't claim to know what really happened, but official governmental reports, especially initial reports, are highly suspect, regardless of who is Commander in Chief.

Per various media sources, the attack was not by full-throttled high speed boat. It was a slow boat previously feigning assistance in a refueling operation until it sauntered alongside; the suicide bombers stood in salute awaiting the explosion.

Assuming the facts are as portrayed, the story is not newsworthy in that nothing scandalous or out of the ordinary occurred. Yemen is a war zone, however undeclared, and two US operatives defended themselves from an armed threat. If the men were not supposed to be out on their own, that deserves internal review. If the Yemeni government is weakening or the country is moving closer to failed-state status prompted in any way by a sloppy drone targeted-killing campaign, hopefully the people in charge can figure out the corrective measures needed. The Afghan, Pakistani, and Yemeni peoples all oppose American drone strikes that cause collateral damage.  While the attacks are in our mutual interests, our "allies" are the ones who suffer civilian deaths, while our pilots remain out of harm's way.  Drones are a great advance militarily.  But politically, they're pretty much a disaster.  They help us target terrorists but also enrage the civilian populations.  Often, when we eliminate a terrorist, we cause an innocent death which, in turn, causes public outrage.  It's become something of a zero sum game and, IMO, it may well be a waste of time, money, and civilian lives.

Is it only me? I grew up in the military (a "brat," as we were called), and always enjoyed reading books that were set in exotic foreign countries and involved psychological warfare and CIA "spooks." So these sentences in this article understandably caught my attention: "American officials refused to identify the Americans or their jobs in Yemen....(A) senior American official said one individual involved in the shooting was a lieutenant colonel with the elite Joint Special Operations Command..."

But then I GOT it. Against a background of drone strikes, "seething resentment in Yemen," fears of erupting violence and Al Qaeda "strongholds," this report sounds like an assassination took place in that barbershop.

Is this fiction? Or reality?

I'm not saying the official US version of those story is in any way inaccurate, but given the history of past claims about such incidents it would be wise to take a closer look. The military and the government have created their own credibility problems and they have to live with the lack of trust they have earned.

We're in Yemen to defend ourselves against a very dangerous terrorist threat.  When we justly kill off would-be kidnappers you'd think it would be good news.  But if that success endangers our people on the ground and causes public anti-American furor, you're celebrating a marked deterioration in our strategic position.  Those whose understanding lies at the surface are like dolphins who judge the world from what they see in the short time when they come up for air.

After seeing "Ghost" in a San Isidro theater, I and my fiancée, well-dressed, took a cab to return home in Miraflores. Instead of driving directly down well-lit Arequipa Blvd, deserted at that hour of the morning, the driver turned aside to the throughway, "El Sanjón," which he nervously claimed would be faster. I'd lived there for years and knew how dark it was. It was not faster.

I demanded he turn around. He didn’t answer, nor complied. Powerfully built, his face revealed determination. He wouldn’t look at me. My fiancée, a careful, self-possessed woman from the high jungle, where danger from the Shining Path was then a constant, was clearly distressed. I forced the driver to turn around, to take Arequipa Blvd and then drop us off at Kennedy Park in Miraflores. He tried to charge us for the ride. I loudly called to police officers 30 meters away, and the driver sped off.

HURRAY! for the Embassy officers who defended themselves, who saved their families from the loss of husband, father, friend!

The only certainty in this episode is that we will be left with uncertainty, that the information needed to evaluate what was going on will be classified.

It is a reminder of our militarized rather than diplomatic approach to the world -- in how many countries do we have some kind of armed forces?? Ooops, that's classified.
